pros: I hadn’t worked in financial services before, but UBS gives you the opportunity to contribute to meaningful work as an intern. It’s a great company to work for and fantastic for your resume and connections.
cons: They tend to not automatically hire interns for positions like some other large banks, so be prepared to have to fight for a position if you want to stay with them after graduation.

pros: Typical ib and you know the same
cons: Long hours are the key reason to this
advice_to_mgmt: Do more to protect junior employees

pros: Very clean and safe environment, lunch areas, convenient location downtown, subsidized parking. Excellent manager in my division, co workers all extremely good at their jobs, no weak links, they have an excellent team.
cons: opportunities to advance are fairly limited....

pros: Lots of good people working at the company. Great opportunity for mentorship.
cons: Large company so need to stay focused to create your own path.

pros: Such a team collaborative environment
cons: Commute isn’t consistent but not bad.

pros: Great people, teamwork, willing to change
cons: WM focus, overly focused on biz cycle (boom//bust)

pros: Decent pay, great people, flexible work hours, and good way to get into the industry
cons: Everything is over the phone, overly strict compliance rules, too many managers

review_title: Nice place but a lot of overhead
pros: Nice and skilled people in my team
cons: A lot of overhead due to the fact that it is a Swiss bank (strict restriction on web navigation, a lot of time to setup the machine, etc)

pros: great for entry level looking to become licensed to sell securities
cons: lower management (who you would be working directly under) don't seem to understand a work life balance. Be prepared for many late nights without additional compensation

pros: Some very talented people work the firm.
cons: Way to much time and effort devoted to 360 reviews—penalizes people working in small groups or those with very specialized skills sets.
advice_to_mgmt: Stop trying to be Goldman Sachs—your not.

pros:
Great atmosphere.
Management is great
Fun Perks
cons: Nothing I would change now.

pros:
People were great

pros: benefits, opportunity, connections, growth, dynamic
cons: Schedule, time commitment, various bosses to answer to

pros: Nice culture with lots of flexibility
cons: Business is not growing fast

pros: Worked with an excellent team. Very educational opportunity to learn more about the facets of finance and gain an understanding of the financial world and terminology.
cons:
19 hour a week maximum time cap on part-time employees.
Pay was minimal or none depending on your team you worked with.

pros:
Some good people to work with
Exposure to many facets of business
Good vacation time benefits
Good work location, home office, availability
cons:
Pay increases are rare
Company always cost cutting
Experienced personnel pool depleted
advice_to_mgmt: Lack of pay adjustments, and continuous cost cutting will eventually leave you with personnel with 2-5 year experience levels. A very short sighted approach.

pros: Lots of hands on experience
cons: Overwhelming workload during trading hours

pros: great atmosphere, new technology
cons: don't fairly review people work

pros: Aggressive sign up bonuses
cons: Very short term across division.

pros: Good company to have on your resume
cons: Poor culture in the office. Everybody has their own practice.

pros: Great people to work with.
cons: Some Managers can be micromanagers, which is not the best for people that like autonomy. You will spend more time in meetings than actually working on your stuff.

review_title: Good to start with your career
pros: good organization, good people to work with
